title: Toronto Argonauts' Greg Jones does it all (and well)
text:
Argos QB Trevor Harris could be next face of franchise 
The one constant at linebacker for the Toronto Argonauts has been Greg Jones, a Super Bowl champion now eyeing a Grey Cup title to add to his professional resume. 
Jones, it seems, is always around the football, whether he is asked to tackle ball carriers in the box or line up on special teams. 
In Ottawa Tuesday night, Jones led the Argos with eight tackles and he also added a team-high three special teams tackles. 
A true pro who dedicated his first interception to his young son, Jones has fully embraced life in the CFL and all the many challenges the league provides with limited roster sizes and players asked to sacrifice a lot. 
On Monday afternoon, the challenge facing Jones and Toronto’s defence is Montreal’s run game, which must be established to take pressure off a very inconsistent Alouettes passing game that can lead to a lot of two and outs if too many attempts hit the turf. 
Tyrell Sutton is a downhill runner, the kind of style that fits Jones’ skill set because he’s very good between the tackles. 
What separates Montreal is its run game. 
Most teams feature scat backs in the backfield, running backs who like to attack the edge and be used as receiving threats. 
“I think our challenge will be consistency,’’ said Jones of the Als’ offence. “We have to keep (consistent) to continue to stop the run, play in, play out. They’ve got a great back in Terrell Sutton and I think they’re going to get him involved in their game play. 
“If they can establish the run, I think it sets up the rest of their packages. We have to play together.” 
What the Argos have done well of late, at least in beating the Ottawa RedBlacks, involves pass drops and zone drops, spacing and tightening the window for quarterbacks when attempting throws. 
No facet of the Argos’ game is far from complete, including the defence, but the unit has been overlooked with QB Trevor Harris throwing as well as he has been, with Chad Owens heading back to Montreal following a punt-return major in Toronto’s first visit to Ottawa and then in the next game, producing that one-handed diving touchdown reception for the game-winner. 
Because of injuries, Jones has had Brandon Isaac, Cory Greenwood, Vincent Agnew, James Yurichuk, Matt Black and Thomas Miles line up next to him this season. 
Isaac is back at strong side with Miles unofficially replacing Greenwood, who played at Concordia but remains out of the Toronto lineup following his second concussion this CFL season. 
When Jones needs a break, Brian Rolle enters the game. 
“Brian came in when I got a little bit winded (in Ottawa) and that’s because I don’t want to let my team down,’’ said Jones. “We work together. Being on special teams and then on defence, that’s part of the game and I understood last year (Jones’ first in Toronto). It’s part of the job.” 
And right now, Jones is doing his job well. 
CUMMINGS AND GOINGS 
Euclid Cummings is quietly coming of age as a dominant CFL defensive lineman, getting better each time he steps on the field, becoming more comfortable in his role and responsibilities. 
In Ottawa, he produced a career-first, a two-sack game as the Argonauts emerged with a late-game win at TD Place Stadium. 
“I’m feeling good,’’ said Cummings. “We’ve got five games left and you can start to see the light at the end of the tunnel. It’s time now to focus in more and get this win.” 
The Double Blue play the host Alouettes on Monday afternoon, one of those matchups where records mean nothing. 
Montreal has shown it can beat the CFL’s elite when the offence is moving the football and avoiding turnovers, when specials teams are solid and when the team’s defence is dominating opponents. 
“I’m thankful for the two sacks and finally my hard work is starting to come out — but I just have to string games together,’’ said Cummings. 
“It’s not about performing in one game. The key is play well over the next five games.” 
Four guys rushing, players being rotated, a defensive line that has anchored the defence in recent weeks, the Boatmen can go a long way in wrapping up a post-season berth if they can put constant pressure on the Montreal quarterback on Monday. 
IT’S ALL ON THE LINE 
One doesn’t have to look far to find the heart and soul of a football’s team makeup when all that’s required is a quick glance at the offensive line. 
At the end of the day, football remains a game won in the trenches, the best teams usually separating themselves from the competition based on the strength of their line play. 
In Toronto’s past two games, both wins over the RedBlacks, both games played in Ottawa, the Argonauts’ defensive line was asked to contain QB Henry Burris rather than pad stats by going for sacks. 
While the Argos aren’t exactly a run team, the offensive line did provide enough protection for Double Blue QB Trevor Harris, who enters Monday’s game in Montreal by coming off a five-touchdown performance. 
Toronto lost starting right tackle Chris Van Zeyl with a calf injury and all kinds of options have been explored. 
While nothing is ever etched in stone, Greg Van Roten has now surfaced as a possible starter against the Als. 
Van Roten, who played for the NFL’s Green Bay Packers, has a high football IQ and he’s very versatile having started the season as Toronto’s starting centre when veteran Jeff Keeping was unable to play. 
Van Roten was initially pencilled in as Toronto’s starting guard, but he can play all positions. 
Van Roten and Tyler Holmes are the only offensive linemen to start every game for the Argos, who face a big test against Montreal’s well-rested and desperate defence, a unit that is more than capable of rising to the occasion. 
Van Roten and Holmes are arguably the leading candidates to emerge as Toronto’s top offensive lineman when members of the media soon begin voting on the various awards. Sponsored Links
